items.title: Skier dies after falling into deep snow at Banff resort
items.summary_auto: A 47-year-old woman died on Saturday after falling into deep snow while skiing at Sunshine Village in Banff National Park. She has been transported to Calgary for an autopsy to confirm the cause of death.

items.title: Russia says its negotiating stance on Ukraine will toughen after accusing Kyiv of attack
items.summary_auto: The Kremlin said Tuesday its position would toughen in talks on ending the war in Ukraine after accusing Kyiv of attacking a Russian presidential residence — an allegation that Kyiv said was baseless and intended to prolong the conflict.

items.title: Trump says U.S. struck dock on shore where he says alleged drug boats 'load up'
Year of Manitoba landfill searches shows reconciliation a work in progress, families say
items.summary_auto: The year that saw the remains of two First Nations women brought home from a Manitoba landfill and a search get underway for the remains of a third showed how far reconciliation efforts have come — and how far they still need to go, the families say

items.title: The books that explained 2025 (Part 2)
items.summary_auto: Part two of our series with some of our favourite guests of the year, on what they read to better understand 2025.

items.title: N.B. Premier Susan Holt doesn’t know why no one knew how to cut gas price sooner
items.summary_auto: Premier says the oversight meant New Brunswickers paid too much for gas during the past few years, as a cheaper form of gasoline became more widely used.

items.title: After years on their back foot, here's why Democrats are feeling good about 2026
items.summary_auto: For much of the last two years, the U.S. Democratic Party has been on its back foot, enduring painful electoral defeats to an omnipresent Republican opponent while grappling with a troubling decline in voter registration and a listless party base. But in the closing days of 2025, the political pendulum appears to be swinging in their direction.

items.title: Many Canadians are spending less time with friends. How can we build deeper connections?
items.summary_auto: After tragedy struck their team, the Toronto Dingos turned to a simple weekly tradition — sharing video life updates — creating a culture of connection that experts say highlights why friendship matters more than ever.

items.title: Courthouse canines help ease the tension, one tail wag at a time
items.summary_auto: Therapy dogs and their volunteer handlers from Just Paws are a welcome presence at the Ottawa Courthouse, where the stress can be hard to handle alone.

items.title: What's coming up next in Canadian politics? Here are five key stories to watch in 2026
items.summary_auto: 2026 is shaping up to be an action-packed year in Canadian politics. Federal opposition parties will make key decisions on their futures as the Liberal government, just one seat shy of a majority government, strategizes what to do next while juggling U.S. trade talks. Here are five key stories to keep an eye on next year.

items.title: Elbows up in 2025: How a year of Canadian boycotts on U.S. products played out
items.summary_auto: Here are a few of the ways Canadians tried to put more power behind their purchase and travel choices in 2025 — and how those decisions may have impacted the U.S. economy.

items.title: Canada cruises past Denmark at men's world junior hockey championship
items.summary_auto: Gavin McKenna scored a hat trick as Canada finally flexed its muscles at the world junior championship in a 9-1 victory over Denmark on Monday night.

items.title: China launches live-firing drills around Taiwan in 2nd day of exercises aimed at further isolating the island
items.summary_auto: China launched 10 hours of live-firing exercises around Taiwan on Tuesday, the second day of Beijing's largest-ever war games around the island, aimed at swiftly cutting its links to outside support in the event of a conflict.

items.title: This retired B.C. couple escaped fire twice in 2025
items.summary_auto: Ritchie and Rene Day were enjoying a quiet evening in their unit at Johnny’s Motel in Grand Forks when they heard banging on their unit’s door on the evening of Dec. 21. “We just couldn't believe it,” said Ritchie Day from her son’s house. “Another fire.”

items.title: Woman who killed son should be able to see her other children, lawyer says
items.summary_auto: A mother who stabbed her one-year-old infant during psychosis should not be prevented from seeing her other children, a lawyer told a board tasked with reviewing her case.

items.title: Northeast B.C. measles outbreak to continue into 2026, health officials say
items.summary_auto: Six months after a measles outbreak first began in northeast B.C., Northern Health says the virus will continue to circulate in the region well into 2026, prolonging the strain on healthcare workers and keeping vulnerable people at risk.

items.title: Pimicikamak Cree Nation declares state of emergency after power outage in northern Manitoba
items.summary_auto: Residents of a northern Manitoba First Nation are being told that their power will not be restored until late in the day on New Year’s Eve. Pimicikamak Cree Nation declared a state of emergency on Monday following a widespread power outage in the Cross Lake area around 11:30 p.m. Sunday.

items.title: Duty free shops say they're still losing sales as Canada-U.S. cross-border travel plummets
items.summary_auto: Owners of duty free shops in Windsor and Sarnia say they continue to suffer the fall-out from the U.S. trade war, seeing drops in business in the 30 per cent range year over year.

items.title: Couple from Gatineau, Que., found dead while vacationing in Dominican Republic
items.summary_auto: The son of Alain Noël and Christine Sauvé found their bodies inside the couple's vacation home on Boxing Day, the family told Radio-Canada.

items.title: Trump has the power to make Putin accept peace plan, says Ukrainian MP
items.summary_auto: Ukrainian MP Oleksiy Goncharenko says he doesn’t believe Russia is interested in a peace deal with Ukraine, but he hopes U.S. President Donald Trump will use his influence to make one happen anyway.

items.title: Chevy Chase's comedy and quarrels are in the spotlight in a new documentary
items.summary_auto: In the new film I'm Chevy Chase and You're Not, set to premiere on New Year's Day, Chase reflects on a dark childhood and a complicated career that spans the very beginnings of Saturday Night Live to a rocky tenure on sitcom Community.

items.title: Vancouver Whitecaps reach proposed settlement in lawsuit seeking damages for 2024 Messi no-show
items.summary_auto: Fan alleged "bait-and-switch" in lawsuit launched after international superstars Lionel Messi, Luis Suarez and Sergio Busquet didn't show up as advertised with Inter Miami to play the Vancouver Whitecaps.

items.title: 'Frustration at its pinnacle:' Ontario newcomers anxious over immigration overhaul
items.summary_auto: Concerned about recent changes to immigration in Ontario, Muhammad Haseeb Ahmad is anxiously awaiting word on whether he can become a Canadian permanent resident.

items.title: Tiger Woods turns 50. It's the one time golf's greats can relate to him
items.summary_auto: Talk to any golfer who played against Tiger Woods and there is sure to be at least one story about one shot so sublime they were certain it could not be hit by them or anyone else. He was just different. Better.

items.title: Beyoncé becomes fifth musician to join the billionaire club
items.summary_auto: The elusive pop star can credit her massive catalogue of hits and high-grossing tours for pushing her into 10-figure territory, according to Forbes — though a few business ventures, concert films and live performances have added to her wealth.
